definition: to lift/to carry in one's hand/Taiwan pr. [ling1]
"hand" radical in Chinese characters (Kangxi radical 64), occurring in 提, 把, 打 etc
classifier for a ream of paper
to order/to command/an order/warrant/writ/to cause/to make sth happen/virtuous/honorific title/season/government position (old)
to pick up (from the ground with one's hands)

sentences.english: He went in carrying his suitcase.
She reached down, picked up a suitcase, and put it back in the van.
sentences.chinese: 她彎下腰，拎起一個手提箱放回貨車裏。

sentences.english: Cuiping finally realized her act and took the pipe and went out bare foot to the balcony.
sentences.chinese: 倒是翠平猛然醒悟過來，拎着菸袋光着腳跑到陽臺上。

sentences.english: Eve said, I'll get a bucket of water.
sentences.chinese: 伊芙說，“我去拎一桶水來。”

sentences.english: Bags are often carried by women.
sentences.chinese: 通常都是女人拎着大包小包。

sentences.english: and the sight of everyone carrying bags bulging with food.
sentences.chinese: 以及人人手裏大包小包拎着鼓鼓囊囊食品袋的景象。

sentences.english: The mother rises and picks up her knitting.
sentences.chinese: 母親站起身，拎起她的毛線活兒來。

sentences.english: There's often someone with a squeaky toy standing behind the camera.
sentences.chinese: 比如常有人拎着一隻吱嘎響的娃娃站在攝影機後。

sentences.english: Sometimes life is going to hits you in the head with a brick.
sentences.chinese: 有時候，生活會拎起一塊板兒磚拍你的腦袋。

sentences.english: I do not know the mountain of public dollars, it got picked up the broom to clean up the cages.
sentences.chinese: 山公不知是計，它拎起條帚鑽進鐵籠就清掃起來。

sentences.english: You just pick up your bag and leave, Maria.
sentences.chinese: 瑪麗亞，你只要拎起包走就行了。

sentences.english: If in doubt, 25 cents for each bag he carries is satisfactory.
sentences.chinese: 如果拿不定主意，每拎一個包給25美分就行了。

sentences.english: He opened up a cage and lifted out a 6ft python.
sentences.chinese: 他打開籠子，拎出一條6英尺長的蟒蛇。

sentences.english: Then the bear wiped his ass with the rabbit.
sentences.chinese: 於是熊就拎起兔子擦了屁股。

sentences.english: I took the empty barrel and went towards the well outside the yard.
sentences.chinese: 我拎起空桶向院外的水井走去。

definition: to pick up (from the ground with one's hands)
to attempt all tasks at once/to manage every detail regardless of its importance
to swing (one's arms, a heavy object)/to wave (a sword, one's fists)/to fling (money)
to put into (one's pockets, clothes)/Taiwan pr. [chuai3]
to carry on one's shoulder/(fig.) to take on (a burden, duty etc)
to raise aloft with both hands/(of two or more people) to carry sth together
